title: Biased and Unbiased Estimators
question_text: A poll was recently taken asking local citizens about their opinions on the mayor's recent speech. A random sample of $200$ local citizens was taken. If, instead of randomly sampling $200$ citizens, $500$ citizens were sampled, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The increased sample size will reduce the bias of the poll result.
The increased sample size will reduce the variability of the poll result.
The increased sample size will reduce the effect of nonresponse on the poll.
The increased sample size will reduce the variability of the opinions.
The increased sample size will be less accurate when representing the opinions of the entire city.

solution:
Solution

Increasing the sample size from $200$ to $500$ reduces the variance, or the spread, of values of the statistic displayed in the sampling distribution. The larger the sample, the less likely it is to get extreme values (small and large). In addition, the larger the sample size, the closer the sample is to the actual population that is being studied.

So, Choice 'B' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘A’ is incorrect. Bias is present when a statistic tends to overestimate or underestimate a parameter. Bias can result from many reasons, including sampling or measurement errors, or unrepresentative samples. The size of the sample does not have an effect on the bias that is or is not present.

Choice ‘C’ is incorrect. Nonresponse occurs when subjects chosen to be part of a sample refuse to participate. The size of a sample has no effect on the nonresponse rate.

Choice ‘D’ is incorrect. While increasing the sample size decreases the variance of a statistic, like $\bar{x}$ or $\hat{p}$, it does not decrease the likelihood of any one respondent from responding in a certain manner. In both small and large samples, it is possible (and sometimes likely) to get extreme values from one subject.

Choice ‘E’ is incorrect. As stated in the solution above, the larger the sample, the closer the sample is to the actual population that is being studied and will thus be more accurate in representing the population being studied.
